Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Data-Fusion Imaging Observatory for Space and Solid Earth
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Aeronomy and Magnetospheric Physics Programs in the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences in the Directorate for Geoscience, and the Earthscope Program in the Division of Earth Sciences in the Directorate for Geoscience.

The investigators will develop a self-consistent data-fusion algorithm that will simultaneously image the ground conductivity and ionospheric parameters based on magnetic field measurements and incoherent scatter radar measurements. The solar wind, magnetosphere, ionosphere, and atmosphere are coupled to Earth?s crust and mantle through electromagnetic induction, with geomagnetically induced currents (GICs) deep into the Earth. However, current assumptions and simplifications limit the interpretation of observations. Ionospheric currents are derived from ground-level magnetic perturbations without knowledge of the conductivity in the crust and mantle. Conversely, variations in conductivity of the crust and mantle assume that the ionosphere radiates a plane electromagnetic wave that drives currents through the varied ground-conductivity distribution. The source-strength is factored out of the analysis by forming the impedance from the magnetic and electric fields measured at ground level. The apparently inconsistent assumptions have been reconciled through statistical methods, but the effects of these assumptions are unknown. Near Fairbanks, under the auroral oval, is a multibeam incoherent scatter radar (Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR), with a multispectral all sky imager (ASI), and an imaging Fabry Perot interferometer. The National Geoelectromagnetic Facility (NGF) is a repository of magnetotelluric (MT) sensors that will include EarthScope?s Transportable Array to be deployed in Alaska. The combined data sets will allow the first testing of the fundamental paradigm concerning the source of ground-electromagnetic perturbations---a paradigm that has been challenged by a growing number of controversial papers identifying electromagnetic precursors to earthquakes, and that does not normally account for magnetic permeability. This fundamental paradigm also governs the GIC hazard, which, for the first time, will be analyzed with full knowledge of the ground conductivity and ionospheric current. The data-fusion algorithm to be developed will numerically solve the geoelectromagnetic induction problem and determine if the full suite of ground and ionospheric measurements can be rendered consistent, and with what accuracy. Any deviations will be investigated and their physical cause sought, thereby opening the door to new discoveries. Assuming that any inconsistencies can be resolved, the data will be fused to produce time-evolving three-dimensional images of auroral arcs, including the full three-dimensional current system that connects them to the magnetosphere through field-aligned currents. The first three-dimensional view of the electrical conductivity structure of the Alaskan lithosphere and upper mantle will also be produced, along with a two-dimensional transect of the Alaska margin, through the cordillera, and into cratonic North America beyond. The scientific results will guide development of an empirical model for the GIC hazard by identifying the needed descriptors of ground conductivity and geomagnetic activity. A postdoc and a graduate student from a traditionally underrepresented group will be trained in interdisciplinary research through their involvement with the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF's INSPIRE program has enabled investigation of foundational assumptions used to model electrical coupling between the magnetosphere, ionosphere, and solid-earth, which has eluded the reach of more traditional NSF programs. The studied assumptions are used broadly throughout space- and solid-earth-physics for modeling and interpretation of data. Assumptions made for expediency, early in the development of a field, have a tendency to become codified as more and more research comes to depend on them. Later, when methods for validating the assumptions become available, researchers may resist validation, both because confidence in the assumptions has become programmed, and also because they fear that a large body of research could be compromised. The INSPIRE program has allowed these difficulties to be overcome for the nearly iconic assumption of electrostatic equilibrium, which this research finds to be contraindicated under common conditions. 

The investigation combines theoretical analysis with observations made in the high-latitude auroral region. A temporary array of 24 magnetotelluric sensors was installed over an approximately 200 km x 300 km wide region in the interior of Alaska. The electric and magnetic field data from these sensors can, in principle, be predicted from sufficiently detailed measurements of the ionospheric current through a self-consistent characterization of the underground conductivity. The latter characterization is normally accomplished from magnetotelluric sensor data alone, using an assumption of uniformity for the ionospheric source, not thought to be valid in the auroral region. 

The sensor array was positioned under the field of view of the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (operated by SRI International) and the Poker Flat all-sky imager (operated by University of Alaska, Fairbanks). The ionospheric source-current was inferred by combining the 2D resolution of the imager with the multibeam line-of-sight resolution of the radar, using regularization and the critical assumption that electric fields map along geomagnetic fields lines, which is derived from the assumption of electrostatic equilibrium.

Using the method of downward continuation, we projected the associated magnetic fields to the surface of the Earth and compared them to those actually measured at the 24 locations. Generally we find agreement, although deviations in the orientation and intensity are sometimes significant, especially during times of geomagnetic disturbance. This allowed us to establish that, although the inferred ionospheric current-system contains highly apparent structures, they do not substantively affect ground-level magnetic perturbations, even for moderately active conditions in the auroral zone. This result allowed us to apply traditional analysis methods to the magnetotelluric data.

We have assembled the first 2-D and 3-D images of the electrical properties of the crust and upper mantle in the interior of Alaska, in a region where the Pacific Plate subducts beneath the Alaska continental crust at a shallow angle, and where the subduction process ends and the thicker lithosphere of stable, older "cratonic" North America begins.

However, the results also mean that we cannot confirm the electrostatically derived ionospheric structures from the ground-magnetic perturbations. Therefore, we applied theoretical analysis to this problem. We developed an electromagnetic transmission-line model for ionospheric disturbances and compared it against electrostatic predictions. The complete set of waves filling the ionospheric "transmission line" was derived using an exact eigenvector analysis of the electromagnetic five-moment fluid equations. The steady-state wave-characteristics needed for the transmission line model were derived from the usual Laplace transform techniques. It is well known that such transmission line models reproduce electrostatically derived lumped-element circuit models under the condition that the wavelength is large compared to the circuit size. In the case of the ionosphere, the analogous condition is that the geomagnetic-field-aligned wavelength is large compared to the ionospheric thickness. 

However, this crucial condition was found to be violated in the ionosphere, due to shortening of the Alfven wavelength in the E region and subsequent dissipation of that mode. Mode transition to the highly electromagnetic whistler wave could allow energy to continue through the E region, but since the whistler mode is cut off above E-region altitudes, the wavelength-shortening of the Alfven mode affects waves with sufficiently small transverse wavelength. We found that the wavelength along the geomagnetic field is not sufficiently long to justify the electric-field mapping assumption when the transverse scale-size is less than about 100 km. Highly significant differences in conductivity and dissipation scale length were also found. 

Hence, the new analysis predicts breakdown of the electrostatic assumption in the E region ionosphere for transverse scales less than about 100 km, and the data-comparison, while revealing broad agreement consistent with earlier findings, left plenty of room for the new results. A specification has been obtained for the transmission line model, which can replace the electrostatic model in many cases. The submitted paper generated some controversy and stimulated discussion of the results. Thus, by the measure of the INSPIRE program, which is designed to fund higher-risk, possibly controversial research, the study was a success.
